Based on your preference cues, I would recommend "A Separate Peace" and "Scream 4". 

"A Separate Peace" is a classic novel by John Knowles that explores themes of friendship, love, loyalty, and sacrifice. The story follows two students named Louis Macauley and Phoebe Cates who attend an elite prep school in New England during World War II. The two friends initially have very different attitudes toward the war, and they eventually come to terms with each other's perspectives. However, their friendship is ultimately tested by a series of tragic events that occur over the course of several years after graduation from prep school in New England during World War II.

I would highly recommend Jumper for its intriguing plot and talented cast. The story follows a young man with teleportation abilities who suddenly finds himself in the middle of an ancient war between those like him and their sworn annihilators. As he tries to survive in this hostile environment, the young man must also confront his own inner demons and struggle against the overwhelming odds if he wants to emerge victorious from this epic battle.
Other great movies that you might enjoy include:
- Annie Hall: A classic romantic comedy directed by Woody Allen. The movie follows the story of Alvy Singer, a divorced Jewish comedian, who reflects on his relationship with ex-lover Annie Hall, an aspiring nightclub singer, which ended abruptly just like his previous marriages.
- Jumper: An action-packed sci-fi thriller directed by Greg Mottola and Matthew Modine. The movie follows the story of Jason Parker, a young man with teleportation abilities who suddenly finds himself in the middle of an ancient war between those like him and their sworn annihilators.

Based on your preferences for war stories and involving diverse characters, here are some potential recommendations:

- "The White Countess" (1995) is a historical drama based on the novel of the same name by Robert Harris. The story takes place in Italy during World War II, and follows the relationship between an American diplomat who has lost his sight in an accident, and a beautiful Russian woman who works as a prostitute to support her aristocratic family's debts.

- "The End of the Affair" (1995) is a romantic drama based on the novel of the same name by Ian Fleming. The story takes place in London during World War II, and follows the relationship between an American doctor who has lost his wife in an accident, and a beautiful Russian woman who works as a prostitute to support her aristocratic family's debts.

- "Saving Private Ryan" (1998) is a war drama based on the novel of the same name by John P. Ullrich. The story takes place in Europe during World War II, and follows the experiences of a group of United States Army soldiers who are part of a combat unit that was dropped behind enemy lines and tasked with retrieving a paratrooper who is missing from the unit.

- "Braveheart" (1995) is a historical drama based on the novel of the same name by William Shakespeare. The story takes place in Scotland during the Wars of Scottish Independence, and follows the experiences of a brave warrior named Robb Bellanger who fights against the English army commanded by Lord Robert Sutherland, and his son Robert, to protect their homeland from invasion and exploitation.

Based on the preferences and genre cues provided, here are some potential recommendations:

- Title: Casablanca  (1942)  | Plot: A cynical expatriate American cafe owner struggles to decide whether or not to help his former lover and her fugitive husband escape the Nazis in French Morocco.  | Starring: Claude Rains, Humphrey Bogart, Conrad Veidt
- Title: Alex in Wonderland  (N/A)  | Plot: Bohemian Alex Morrison has just finished directing his first feature-length movie. In its previews, the movie is considered a critical, artistic, and surefire commercial success, so Alex seemingly has his choice of what his next project will be. Alex has a few ideas, like a biopic of Lenny Bruce or a movie about a black uprising in Los Angeles. As he makes the rounds of both the Hollywood community and European movie centers for ideas, he fantasizes about movie scenarios of his everyday situations, influenced by his movie idols, some of whom he actually meets, like Italian director Federico Fellini and French actress Jeanne Moreau. He' s also wondering what to do about his personal life: does it make sense for him to  "move up" with his wife Beth and their two daughters from their middle-class lifestyle? If so, filmmaking must not only achieve his main purpose of saying something meaningful, but also must be commercially successful. But must the need for commercial success ultimately take artistic control out of his hands?
